column1: My name is Urtė and I hate writing. Problematically, though, good texts haunt me while I walk the streets

tier two: for years now, I’ve been trying to tame the meanings that flow into the city. In gratitude for what I’ve gained, I offered my own words -

which is to say, I placed new street names and old names of loved ones horizontally and vertically, making maps to not get lost, to not lose. It led to

tier four: Vincent, a Taxi Driver no one could guess his age imagine youth in old man’s face with dripping eyes and eyelids interfering with his glance “I read the stars” he says believing his sun in leo has engraved the maple husk that grows in shade with signs unknown to human race of how the sky has predetermined fate refuse your doubts his mimics ask to be heard out despite the fact that reading stars is such an egoistic conversation start the way he tries to barge into the sky imposing shapes of animals that crawl through ages in a circle around the axis of one’s self is action done not only by some little men you do that every morning time and time again redialling the focus to the face in front you see internal cosmos bursting out for long it navigated esoteric roads and helped his passengers with horoscopes “so what’s your sign?” he asks though knows the answer and counts to twelve in baritone the seconds one still has before the night comes and whelms bones in raging storms of the unknown Now a Woman her glowering morning face in mirror surface touches traits unseen each night the old face looses fights against deteriorating cells never protected from uv or dust that rises during draught and settles like it must in entropy she put her trust to make each speck find place to make a trust fall catch herself thinking about the dreams of particles of past (meaning two people together in attraction taking leaps of faith) that drowned in shifting floodgates and communicating vessels failing to settle tears at constant levels while testing how much time has passed since rain was mystic eyes were trusting the laws turn tables and one human hand won’t stop the fall of gravity or even her own loss An Anonym truth be told no words are left his mouth feels odd volition’s gone his eyes glare up again foretelling rain the sly smile of full moon looks feigned the sound of ice in swirling glass against the voices of old friends evokes in him a sense of cold he doesn’t know how many drinks or years it’s been each day is same contemptuously people look at him and say “you’ve changed” another night when he disclaims he’s fallen down the drain together with the deluge forgetting things he swore to cherish repeating “three strikes and I’m out” although new moon has witnessed the time that what was supposed to be the last the only words he now remembers from the Bible (he read the shortened version as a kid) are guiding him while raindrops blur his vision he begs for mercy from his father son and holy spirit An Insomniac insomnia her dearest friend makes turning of the same old tape a gruesome tale a reminiscence of a journey way down south comes up in mind all matter was to freeze in time and capture all the broad-leaved trees in zenith the sun has stopped Apollo looked at her from the above in love all life was still only one thing remained her unexpected steps that moved like pebbles thrown aslant to beat the water surface she walked as if she owned her freedom and as Apollo kissed her feet they synchronised into one rhythmic breathing the voice of memories appears in songs in lullabies for what’s been lost She Who Lives on the Fifth Floor at times of day when the sun loses its potency mosquitos come in flocks like poplar fluff and occupy the city to mock the pale sides of your arms she opens eyes the day has passed it’s safe to rise at times of day when nine-to-fivers sit in traffic jams the city beats and pulses turning on its lights asphalt concrete returns the heat it gathered during day she opens curtains the day has passed retrieving brightness’ burden at times of day when breakfast means a can of beer she sits in silence overlooking evening semblance the faces of the tired people hopeful people hopeless people and those that almost disagree to be so easily misjudged she bends a finger for a man who back in time would have completely broken her obsessive heart for every black stray cat she would have bent to pet for all the kids in strollers pushchairs buggies by whom she would have wished to be called ‘ma’ at times of day when all her fingers are in fists the dawn is heralded by garbage trucks and though the fists have power somewhere deep within to fight the morning light (to threaten in at least) she nonetheless retreats inside she closes curtains closes eyes her hands twitch slightly just before a dreamless dream takes on Stanislav, Age 23 a birthmark by his eye more truthful than one’s eyes could ever be is turned towards the east sunken in colour of the wheat laid out by gusts of wind in motherland a man must stand as stone that’s what his father told to always roll uphill to hold your shoulders up in nausea of stepping on his own he now stands as a wooden cross alone at luring crossroads where only vagrants come to pray to gods of early days for once he’s free to go to not turn back and leave behind sunflowers by the barn (they sprouted unexpectedly pretending to be blooms of fern) he smiles at childish dreams holds back the tears the past and future have dissolved into the daily crumbs of bread he ploughs the distant lands ahead A Girl Lost in Time (29 19 2020) in loving memory of rustling cities and their pigeons she draws an image with her dirty fingers of how she misses kissing cheeks for one goodbye like twenty times or picking up the dimes she’d find for luck but only when they are heads up of how she used to try to tame the pigeons with fervour flapping wings collecting karmic seeds for their religions not caring about who she was of how her father left before he found a moment to explain the heads of hogs that hung in all the taverns by the doors of how her memory is so unkempt (she says that pigeons made the mess) presenting patches of past lives she might have only dreamt of how eternal lines of time cascade and days just drip from fingers on an empty page perhaps because the frozen image of the self is made from dust with no god’s help

tier three: “a sailor who believed in no god”
tier four:
at last the sea disarms to give
or take back what is hers

while back in time the shore was there to keep
the sailor safe from sound
of crashing waves that he will later claim
his own short legs would jump
when getting close
but never going in too deep for safety
holding mother’s hand
by wrist and waving it exemplary
like teaching baby to ‘bye bye’
in voice a pitch too high to mark
with an assertive shade of blue
the ending of the day for those
who haven’t seen horizon past the noon

while now he took the loops and holes of rod
and dipped inside and splashed till soaking
wet hands started slipping out his scales
weighting oblivion or oracle to trust
both warning him against voyage
too late as voices reached him taking off
to what he knew only from tales
that wiggled not like omen but the truth
of how the gospels’ sound stripped down
to red horizons that evaporate all past
engraving salt into the fins as maps
for reading of his always changing paths

the sailor can’t be caught on the radar
his mother wails and prays him back

1.
amorphous truths are hardly seen
especially when running down the cheek
like sap from birches oddly luscious
out of the season attracting multitudes of bees
whose humming never came and never
stopped in fifty years to be
so I could show it to my grandkids
to blow kisses on their swollen
toes need to be cooled down and once again
warmed up for as long as it hurts
to not see through the splashing sap
how bees are not afraid to die
for what they know stinging is worth

  2.
incredulous I choose to sink
in honey hoping weight will show
what crown is gold and what is fraud
but neck can’t hold for what it’s worth
my head folds down upon the draining sink
from which the echoes offer me
a drink the mirror image holds so tight
with eyes she’s scratching my old
insect bites from humid tropic showers
where queens of bees are ruling worlds
but my own steaming flesh there fails to feel
embalming within fingertips
that grip old bricks and swiftly mount
mirages of great pyramids will need
some sand and reminiscences to see
from up the top so far as seas
where are no birds that’d care for what is sweet
the phantoms gliding never in my reach

tier two: I wrote emails and love letters and
tier three: gradually they both started sounding too much alike.
that was influenced by pain that was all around, and yet very far away. I put it all under the title
“Anticipatory Grief in Light of Søren Kierkegaard and Simone Weil: Making Sense of the Task of Loving the Dying”
tier four: The paper aims to explore the notion of anticipatory grief - a form of emotional trajectory connecting a griever and a dying person - in relation to Søren Aabye Kierkegaard and Simone Weil. The main goal is to see how the philosophers can shed light on the relevance and limits of anticipatory grief. By conducting a literature review, the paper argues that Kierkegaard and Weil can mutually illuminate anticipatory grief as a moral attitude that is born out of love and, through attention, gets directed to those who are about to die. Kierkegaard’s thoughts can elucidate the potential of the concept of anticipatory grief to embody the Christian command to love one’s neighbour as oneself. In light of the duty to love, anticipatory grief gets disclosed as a moral relationship with the dying. In the search for the right ways to carry out this relationship, Weil’s concept of attention provides a method of genuine openness, allowing one to become a neighbour of all dying in affliction. The paper concludes that anticipatory grief can be seen as an integral part of an authentic and caring life, significant in disclosing the value of the dying other.
